segments.text: What's your personal opinion of Amtrak?
My personal opinion of Amtrak is that it started off on the wrong foot.
Why?
It started off with its own organization to rethink railroad passenger service.
Well, that's not necessarily bad, but they hired the occupants from the bus line and the airlines to try to make a passenger train over and stay by an airline.
That doesn't work.
They really hired very few railroad passenger people when Amtrak was moved.
they have subsequently hired a fair number of people from the railroads.
And I think that has improved both the relationship between Amtrak and the railroads, because now Amtrak as a corporation has a better understanding of the problems involving those trains.
And it's more willing to work with the railroads to solve problems, rather than in the early 70s use an adversarial position.
The railroads versus Amtrak, Amtrak versus the railroads, nothing really got accomplished.
How did Amtrak have its impact on the services offered?
Did Amtrak have the funds to reinstate most of the services that had been taken out just prior to its emergence?
No, Amtrak, during its early days, never had much funding.
And it lived from year to year.
It could never make any long-range plans.
It also...
Excuse me.
But also... Amtrak was originally supposed to be a profit-making corporation.
Amtrak was established by law as a profit-making organization.
But it's not making profit.
It has never made profit, and it depends on public funds for its survival.
In recent years, it has had enough funding where it can make advanced plans.
It has completely re-equipped its fleet in the last two or three years.
The equipment that it inherited from the railroads were anywhere from, dated from 1935 through 1960 vintage.
Did Amtrak have a problem in that it acquired equipment from various lines and it wasn't standardized?
That's right.
Each railroad had its own design for cars.
They were all worked together, run together, but they all had the same general specifications.
But the railroads running across Dakotas and Montana had a car that were heavily insulated because of the cold pipes and the cold weather.
The railroads running between New York and Florida had a different type of car.
They weren't so heavily insulated.
But each railroad knew its equipment and knew where it should run.
And they were pretty much kept to these roofs.
Well, when Amtrak took over, it mixed all the equipment up.
They would take the Florida cars and send them up to the Washington, Montana area.
And these people up there had never seen those cars before.
And they didn't know what to do to fix them when they went back.
And they took the Montana and Dakota cars and shipped them down to Florida.
People there had the same problem.
Because each other's, they had to do different equipment, electrical equipment, air conditioning equipment.
And then the first winter in Amtrak, one of all those cars that were running across Dakota and Montana were freezing up every trip.
Well, it turns out they were all the Florida cars.
They were using the wrong equipment in the wrong spot.
And it was just things like that when Amtrak was new that were really dumb mistakes.
How did the government handle these problems?
Did the government realize that Amtrak wasn't making as much money as it was supposed to make?
Yes.
In fact, there were several attempts along the way to kill Amtrak.
Really?
But there was always enough senators and congressmen who wanted to see the train run through their cities that kept Amtrak alive.
And that's another problem with Amtrak.
It started off with a core system.
Before it could improve its core system,
the senator of this particular state, or the congressman from this time, insist on having a train through his town.
He was on the House Transportation Committee.
He got his train through his town.
And that train would just lose bunches and bunches of money, but it went from nowhere to nowhere.
They restricted political trains, and Amtrak was saddled with many of them.
There was no rational need for the trains, except it was a political expediency to keep Amtrak alive.
What were some of the benefits that came from the Amtrak takeover?
Well, the one benefit from Amtrak takeover, we did have a nationwide system, and you can make a reservation anywhere in the country fairly quickly.
The railroads had the same type of reservation, but sometimes it took days and days to get that reservation confirmed because they had to wire right from one railroad to another.
Amtrak would
What was the public attitude towards Amtrak?
At first the public was very pleased with Amtrak, that they were going to save the Passion Terrain, restore it to its former glory, and increase all sorts of services.
Although the public became very disillusioned.
There were a lot of hot cars, shipping these cars around the country, people didn't know how to fix them.
I would see cars come out of New Orleans on the Sunset Limit and come to Houston.
The ASP mechanics, Southern City mechanics, used to try to fix the car.
Well, it was not a car they were familiar with, and they would sometimes hold that train for an extra 30 minutes just trying to fix the air conditioning on one sleeping car.
And finally, they'd equip their hands and say, I can fix it.
And so the train would go, and the next station would try to fix it, and that type of thing.
But once Amtrak standardized on its equipment and hired its own mechanical forces, a lot of those problems went away.
About what time did the problems start going away?
Well, in the mid, oh, about 1976 or 7, they started getting these, what they called amp-lead equipment, and more recent.
And these are...
body shell, very similar to the Metroliner trains, which the Pennsylvania Railroad developed in the 1960s.
And they had what they call AM coaches and AM dinettes and AM lounge cars.
They did not have any sticky cars in this configuration.
These were all what we call head-in power.
When the railroad passenger cars all had, were self-contained, they had a battery.
which powered the car when it was down in the scale.
They had generators in these cars which generated electricity and the car would move it.
Sometimes they had steam air conditioning based on a steam boiler in the diesel engine.
And in the winter, all the trains were heated by steam.
Again, the steam boiler in the diesel locomotives, or in the early days, the steam locomotives.
Well, Amtrak has converted the heating power, which says that there is a generator
on the diesel.
And this generator produces all the electricity for the train.
The cars are no longer self-contained.
They don't have any batteries, except for emergency lighting.
They don't have to generate their own power at all.
So as long as everything is working fine on the head end, or there's no problems with the wiring between cars, it works very well.
More recently, Amtrak has taken this same philosophy and gone one step further with their superliner equipment.
The superliners are
They have both sleeping cars, coaches, and dining cars, and lounge cars.
When did these cars start?
These came in about 1980.
Those are very recent.
Very recent.
Yes.
Well, let's see.
What's the current public attitude towards rail travel with these improvements?
I think it's looking at, you know, there's a lot of people who enjoy the train rides.
Let me step back.
In the early 1970s, when Anchorage was first organized, they had what they called advisory councils in different cities in the country.
And I was participating in the advisory council in Houston.
And this is where I was having a lot of problems.
We would just generally talk about things that could do or should be doing could do down the road.
I got very discouraged early on because some of the official that come out of Chicago for the advisory.
Don't not to worry.
All right.
We have a problem.
Only 3% of the population has ridden our train.
We have 97% of the public out there still to go.
Well, that's not true, because you don't have 97% of the public to draw from.
You have maybe at the most 10% of the public to draw from.
The other 90% don't want to spend the time traveling by train.
They want to get there in three hours by air, or they want to drive, or whatever.
So you really, passenger service is a very small market sector that you could possibly draw from.
And then things got progressively worse.
Equipment got more decrepit.
Amtrak could not maintain it.

They were told to make money on dining car service, which the railroad never had been able to do, and railroad drew dining cars sort of as a lost leader, like in a store where they had to price something at low cost to attract patronage.
In about 1980, I would say about the lowest point ever,
They had all this new soup line equipment, all the fancy new ranges and what have you, electric ranges.
And all they were serving was McDonald's type food, but not up to McDonald's standards.
And they took the stewards off the dining car and the waiters.
They had two waiters for a full length dining car.
And people would come in to be served, say a family of four.
And one of them would get served, and five minutes later somebody else would get served.
And it just was not, it was disorganized.
And I remember one trip I took in Chicago to Los Angeles, and I was going to continue riding on Amtrak when I got to Los Angeles.
I was so fed up with the service, the food, the quality of the food and everything.
I was like, I found my first pay phone in Los Angeles, a passenger terminal, call an airline, make a new reservation.
Competing industries are taking away the customers.
But since Graham Clayton, who was formerly president of Southern Railway and president of Amtrak, a lot has happened.
A lot has changed.
He...
Those railroads, he's been in the railroads industry his entire life.
These so-called marketing people or analytical people in Washington who don't know anything about railroads but try to market it.
He gave them short shrift, and they really just told them, shape up or ship out.
He's put quality first.
originally quality food back in the dining cars.
It does have restrictions on how much money you can spend and lose, but things are really looking up.
All the onboard people now are re-employed by Amtrak.
The railroads provide the conductors and breakmen and engineers on most of the routes.
But the big sleeping car attendants, the waiters, and so forth are all Amtrak employees.
If the attitude is looking up, are there any plans to expand the services offered, put more lines out?
Amtrak is out looking at the possibility of new routes, but their funding is limited and they're still trying to improve the service they have.
For example, the train between New Orleans through Houston to Los Angeles only runs three times a week.
Years ago, they should have put that daily, but it had not been able to find it.
Now, for the Louisiana World's Fair, they are putting on a special train from Mobile to New Orleans, which they hope to try to take from this.
The states are also helping support that.
That's this summer.
This summer, that's correct.
What about the possibility of the bullet train from Houston to Dallas?
That's an interesting concept.
I'm interested in seeing if they can finance it.
How do you feel about that?
Do you think it has any future?
I think it has a future.
I think that railroad tracks in eastern Dallas could be a viable... Yeah, if you have sufficient tight... sufficient train.
Recently, Amtrak looked at the possibility of rerouting to Sunset, Memphis, which is the... up to Dallas, then out to El Paso.
That way.
Well, as long as there's only...
Tri-weekly service, you're not going to track people right.
And even if they put that train on daily, it still wouldn't do it because you could only go one direction and make a round trip.

You need to have at least twice a day service on a corridor type route so that people can go up in the morning, do their business, and the other city can return home if you want to try to save the business crowd.
In the 1950s and early 60s, when I used to travel to Dallas on vacation by train, I could go up in the morning and do whatever I wanted to do and come back home that evening.
And people in Dallas used to do the same thing.
But when we'd be down to only one train a day, well, I'd cut out over half of your passenger.
That would add a cost of a motel room for every night onto the price per ticket.
Well, with all the airline service,
Yeah, I mean, it was hard to compete with the Southwest $30 and $40 fares.
Well, was the government this past year threatening to cut funding again?
Uh, I have...
I'm not aware of that.
Amtrak seems to try to secure its return funding, but they are being encouraged to try to cover more of the costs out of the fare box.
And they are doing better.
What did Amtrak have as an impact on, say, the private car owners?
Let me stop that for a second.
Thanks.
OK. As I mentioned earlier, in the 20s, before, there were a lot of affluent people handling their own private railroad cars.
And more recently, a different group, some of them very affluent, some of them just common workers, started buying railroad cars that were owned and operated.
And, well, while Amtrak was very negative about handling these private cars, but now Amtrak realizes that it really doesn't cost them anything to pull these cars.
Why were they negative about pulling the cars?
Really, they weren't set up to handle them.
I would say the people who ran Amtrak at that time were not very loyal to them.
They didn't realize that they would make a lot of money.
at a relatively lower expense than that.
So the private car owner, when he puts his car up to 20, pays for 20 fares, whether it's in one person or 20 people in the car.
Anybody over 20 in the car, there are extra fares of Amtrak.
Gets a minimum of 20 fares up to how it remains on the car.
But Amtrak now realizes that
What were some of the demands?
Well, they wanted work done on their equipment.
Some of the cars were not in too good shape.
There was a whole list of it.
people, agitations on both sides.
And that resulted in an organization formed known as the American Association of Private Car Owners.
And this association had this sort of a buffer between private car owners.
And it resolved a lot of differences and problems.
Many of the problems that were there 10 years ago have been resolved by mutual cooperation and dualization.
Has your club experienced any of these problems in trying to pull its private cars on anti-trainers?
Yes, we've experienced two problems.
One of them, we had a problem with the southern city railroad in that they started switching the car around.
That problem has been resolved.
through our satisfaction, so we have no problem with the impact.
The main problem with the impact is that it's difficult to get them to go to fair.
It may take you months to get a fair quotation back.
And once they give you a fair quotation, they want you to do it immediately.
So that's one of the things.
hopefully work out with Amtrak.
Do you think Amtrak was doing that intentionally to discourage you from?
No, I don't think so.
I think that the main reason Amtrak thought it was involved in animal expeditions was because they realized that the playground chain was a real problem.
Well, let's see.
What about the possibility of mass transit in Houston being solved, the problem of mass transit being solved by rail?
Houston is a very spread out city.
And to make rail viable, it has to be a large quantity of people, with a mass of people, to do one of those buses, and one of them's nice.
I personally voted against metro's rail system.
Why did you do that?
Because I thought it was too much for two little systems.
There are a lot of cities that are looking at all kinds of heavy rail, such as what Houston is, or a massive transit system such as New York has.
What used to be called streetcars is now called light rail.
A light rail system in Houston might work out quite well.
There's a lot of cities that built new light rail systems recently.
San Diego has one that's operationally old.
Well, when you're looking back
is that rail service was declining in the 60s.
Was there any alternative to Amtrak to the government jumping in?
Do you think it was right for the government to jump in and try to save it?
That's a philosophical question, and it's hard to answer.
Yes, I think the rail service does do it.
I am not sure.
The old folks can travel.
Well, that's not really true.
Most towns are trying to organize it.
They have adequate bus service so that if they lost the passenger train, yes, it might be able to use a handful of people, but it's not that.
All right, good.
All in the rows.
Has there been any growth in the popularity of the restoration of old racing roads?
Because you're saying several different classes of people have been involved in cars.
Yes.
Is that a trend?
There are probably more people in cars running in the United States than there were in the United States.
Are they basically rare roads or practically?
Yes, basically true.
There are a number of rare roads.
We got done in Galveston recently.
We had a steam locomotive going to St. Mary's.
And they know how their space is not going to be out of the water.
Last year, .
So that's another .
This year, we will also have
Thank you.
Thank you.
This train was restored .
That's correct.
When it got back to Portland .
So really,
There was a time when the railroads didn't want to deal with that.
The way they didn't want to deal with that is now they realize there's more and more people involved.
There are a lot of problems associated with it.
I understand that you're a local organization, and it's tools for people.
Many people nowadays, especially young children, couldn't afford road management.
We are looking at a railway industry as well.
I don't know.
Thank you for coming.
